item.title: Soldering is Easy workshop report
item.dc:creator: mm
item.description: Terrific night yesterday @ altlab! The workshop started with an intro to electronics leaving the attendees anxious to get down to soldering. Despite that, everyone was focusing their attention on what was being said. Half an hour later the soldering irons were plugged in and the fun started. Hands-on and having fun! Blinking LED KIT … Continue reading "Soldering is Easy workshop report"
item.content:encoded:
Terrific night yesterday @ altlab!
The workshop started with an intro to electronics leaving the attendees anxious to get down to soldering.
Despite that, everyone was focusing their attention on what was being said.
Half an hour later the soldering irons were plugged in and the fun started.


Hands-on and having fun!


Blinking LED KIT


A new Hacker is born ! @Ricardo Castelhano


Here is the final result, everyone leaves with their own blinking gadget.

More photos @flickr

item.content:encoded:
(scroll down for English)

Vamos pegar aleat√≥riamente num motor de passo e tentar descobrir que tipo de motor √©, desenhar um diagrama simples do mesmo.
Depois vamos pegar no ferro de soldar (n√£o h√° que ter meeeeeedo :)) e montar um circuito que permite controlar esse motor a partir de um Arduino ou qualquer outra placa baseada num microcontrolador.
Todo o material √© fornecido e fica para os participantes, sendo apenas necess√°rio trazer ferro de soldar e multimetro (ou esperar que alguma alma caridosa vos empreste).

O n√∫mero de participantes √© limitado pelo que, se disserem que v√™m, contamos MEEESMO convosco

Para inscri√ß√µes e pedidos de informa√ß√£o: workshops /arroba/ audienciazero.org
Lota√ß√£o m√°xima de 10 participantes
S√°bado 13 de Mar√ßo de 2010
AltLab em Cacilhas
14h00m
5‚Ç¨

Let‚Äôs each of us pick up a random stepper and try to find out what kind of stepper it is, draw a simple diagram.
Then pick up the soldering iron (have noooooo fear :)) and assemble a circuit to control that motor from an Arduino or any other microcontroller-based board.
All materials are supplied to the participants and everyone gets to keep them; you‚Äôre just required to bring your own soldering iron and multimeter (or wait a random amount of time to borrow someone else‚Äôs).

The number of participations is limited, therefore, if you tell us you‚Äôll come, we‚Äôll REEEALLY be waiting for you

For registration and information requests: workshops /at/ audienciazero.org
Maximum of 10 participants
Saturday, March 13 2010
AltLab @ Cacilhas
14h00m
5‚Ç¨

item.title: PAPERduino‚Äôs design
item.dc:creator: guibot
item.description: This is a fully functional version of the Arduino. We eliminated the PCB and use paper and cardboard as support and the result is.. the PAPERduino üòÄ This is the the first version of the layout design, next we will try more designs, and other materials. You just need to print the top and the … Continue reading "PAPERduino‚Äôs design"
item.content:encoded:
This is a fully functional version of the Arduino. We eliminated the PCB and use paper and cardboard as support and the result is.. the PAPERduino

This is the the first version of the layout design, next we will try more designs, and other materials. You just need to print the top and the bottom layouts, and glue them to any kind of support you want. We hope that you start making your own boards. If you do, please share your photos with us, we would love to see them

There is no USB direct connection, so to program the paperduino you will need some kind of FTDI cable or adapter. One of this products will be fine:
FTDI cable from Adafruit Industries
FTDI adapter from Sparkfun

Download PDF

Components list:
1 x 7805 Voltage regulator
2 x LEDs (different colors)
2 x 560 Ohm resistors (between 220oHm and 1K)
1 x 10k Ohm resistor
2 x 100 uF capacitors
1x 16 MHz clock crystal
2 x 22 pF capacitors
1 x 0.01 uF capacitor
1 x button
1 x Atmel ATMega168
1 x socket 28 pin
Female and Male headers

Instructions:
Use a needle to puncture the holes for your components.

Don‚Äôt rush, place one component after another and do all the solder work carefully.

Follow the connection lines.

And this should be the final look of your paperduino connections.

item.title: openMaterials :: research project
item.dc:creator: Catarina M.
item.description: My dear friend Kisty Boyle and I recently launched openMaterials ‚Äî a collaborative research project dedicated to open investigation and experimentation with DIY production methods and uses of materials. In the spirit of the open source software and hardware movements, we hope to promote materials to be researched and developed in a public, collaborative manner. … Continue reading "openMaterials :: research project"
item.content:encoded:
My dear friend Kisty Boyle and I recently launched openMaterials ‚Äî a collaborative research project dedicated to open investigation and experimentation with DIY production methods and uses of materials. In the spirit of the open source software and hardware movements, we hope to promote materials to be researched and developed in a public, collaborative manner. We see materials as an open resource, and wish to establish an open process for exploring and sharing knowledge, techniques and applications related to materials science.

I‚Äôll be conducting most of my hands-on research right here at AltLab. We‚Äôd love for you to be involved if you are working in these areas or interested in learning more about smart materials.

item.title: Paper and cardboard circuits
item.dc:creator: Ricardo Webbens
item.description: A couple of years ago i found out on the ‚Äúinternets‚Äù that you don‚Äôt really need a protoboard or a circuit board to make your circuits come to life, the idea was to fold a piece of paper with the circuit design in it (component side and circuit diagram side) and then inserting a piece … Continue reading "Paper and cardboard circuits"
item.content:encoded:
A couple of years ago i found out on the ‚Äúinternets‚Äù that you don‚Äôt really need a protoboard or a circuit board to make your circuits come to life, the idea was to fold a piece of paper with the circuit design in it (component side and circuit diagram side) and then inserting a piece of cardboard in the middle.

The main idea was the eco, recycled ‚Äúthingy‚Äù since circuit boards are not so eco friendly and take a bunch of time to get recycled by our mother earth, also the economic side (paper and cardboard are almost free), instead circuit boarding takes a long time and it‚Äôs hazardous for the environment.


So here‚Äôs what i do :

1- print the schematic you want (be sure to include on the sheet of paper both sides of the schematic (component side and schematic)

2‚Äëfold it (the idea is to fold where the component side meets the schematic)

3‚Äëcut a piece of cardboard and insert it in the middle of the sheet of paper

4‚Äëglue both sides on to the cardboard (now you must have a beautifull circuit board made of cardboard)

5‚Äëwith a needle pierce (component side) all drilling holes into schematic side

6‚Äëinsert the components (resistors, ic, capacitator etc..)

7‚Äëturn it back (schematic side) and start to solder (be sure to folow the traces on the paper), the best way to do this is to simply bend the leads of the components and solder them together, if you have a large area were the lead is not long enough just use a wire or something similar.

8‚Äëhave fun
